definitions.definition: a piece of furniture like a table, often with drawers (= parts like boxes in it with handles on the front for pulling them open), that you sit at to read, write, work, etc.

examples.text: I spend all day sitting at a desk.
The mayor sat behind his desk.
He abandoned a career at sea for a **desk job**.
A very strange request landed on my desk this morning.
She got up from her desk and went to the window.
He was sitting at his desk working when we got home.
I left the file on your desk.
My desk gets very cluttered if I don't clear it at the end of each day.
Papers littered the desk and the floor.
The empty desk suggested she had already gone home.
The manager sat frowning behind his desk throughout the whole interview.
They put me on desk duty for a month.
a computer which takes up less desk space

definitions.definition: a place where you can get information or be served at an airport, a hotel, etc.
definitions.sensetop: at a deskbehind a deskon a desk

examples.text: There was a long queue at the **check-in desk**.
The woman behind the **reception desk** was always on the phone.
We asked the man on the information desk for a map of the city.

definitions.definition: an office at a newspaper, television company, etc. that deals with a particular subject

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from medieval Latin desca, probably based on Provençal desca ‘basket’ or Italian desco ‘table, butcher's block’, both based on Latin discus from Greek diskos.
